@PhilipRocco /13 Anyway, a long answer to a short question. We need to acknowledge poor strategy, we need to address conservative where they are, and we need multiple messages. This is how I increased Dem voting 24% in my 2020 State Senate Race. And why I‚Äôll be hosting workshops teaching this

@PhilipRocco /12 So, we need multiple messages for each topic, & we need to address both Dem messaging and conservative concerns. So, for universal healthcare, I‚Äôm a small business owner, and can talk about how it would improve small business opportunity. That connects with conservatives.

@PhilipRocco /10 it‚Äôs hard to use fear to support unions, or minorities, or abortion rights, because none of these things are universally impactful. We recognize they are important, but often to smaller groups. For Ex, why can‚Äôt we pass universal healthcare? Well, those who have insurance

@PhilipRocco /9 welcome to political psychology. üòÄ So, can we use fear and anger as Dems? It‚Äôs honestly much harder because we have positive solutions based on action. Fear and anger are effective blocking strategies. No CRT! No BLM! No Defund! No Min Wage! No taxes! See how that plays?

@PhilipRocco /8 and the GOP lives in the world of fear and anger - of hatred of others - black, brown, LGBTQ, women, the poor, etc. That sense of loyalty, based on fear actually grows their popularity.

@PhilipRocco /7 Isolating tighter doesn‚Äôt help the Dems because we are a coalition of people. Isolating tighter squeezes people out of our silo - like rural voters, some black and Latino voters. The GOP can get away with it because fear and anger are the 2 most powerful persuasive emotions.

@PhilipRocco /6 so what do we do? First, acknowledge the failure. Next, recognize that we need to adjust our strategy. And to what? To talking with conservatives who are mortified by what the GOP has become. By changing our message - NOT OUR SOLUTIONS - to include reasons they can get behind.
